revision.text:
{{title italic}} {| {{Infobox aircraft begin | name = ''Commando'' | image = American Aircraft in Royal Air Force Service 1939-1945- Consolidated Liberator. CH18793.jpg | caption = Liberator II AL504 ''Commando'' which disappeared on 27 March 1945 | alt = <!-- Alt text for main image --> }} {{Infobox aircraft career | other names = <!--Other names (nicknames, nose art names) this aircraft is known by--> | type = [[Consolidated Liberator II]] | manufacturer = <!-- may differ from the main/original manufacturer of this aircraft's type --> | construction number = <!-- manufacturer's construction number --> | construction date = <!-- either roll-out date or span of time for lengthy projects, whichever seems more appropriate --> | civil registration = <!-- any civil registrations carried by this aircraft --> | military serial = AL504 | radio code = <!-- military radio codes where this is a commonly-used way of identifying this aircraft (eg. US, British, and German military aircraft of WWII --> | first flight = <!-- date of first flight --> | owners = [[Royal Air Force]] | in service = July 1942 – 27 March 1945 | last flight = <!-- date of last flight --> | flights = <!-- number of flights made by this aircraft, usually only relevant for an aircraft no longer flying --> | total hours = <!-- total number of hours flown by this aircraft, usually only relevant for an aircraft no longer flying --> | total distance = <!-- total distance flown by this aircraft, usually only relevant for an aircraft no longer flying --> | status = <!-- status for an aircraft still in service --> | aircraft carried = <!-- type of aircraft carried, usually only for mothership aircraft --> | fate = Disappeared over the North Atlantic Ocean en-route to the [[Azores]] | preservation = <!-- where this aircraft is currently preserved (if it is) --> }} |}
'''''Commando''''' ([[Air Ministry]] [[United Kingdom military aircraft serials|serial number]] ''AL504'') was a very long range [[Consolidated Liberator II]] aircraft adapted for passenger transport, to serve as the personal aircraft of [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom|Prime Minister]] [[Winston Churchill]]. ''Commando'' [[List of aerial disappearances|disappeared without a trace]] on 27 March 1945 over the [[North Atlantic Ocean]], while on a flight from [[RAF Northolt]] to [[Lagens Field]] in the [[Azores]], en route to [[Ottawa]] in [[Canada]]. The cause of the disappearance of the aircraft remains unknown to this day. [[File:Consolidated Liberator - Royal Air Force Ferry Command, 1941-1943. CH8554.jpg|thumb|right|January 1943. AL504 ''Commando'', VIP taxying at Lyneham, Wiltshire, with Winston Churchill on board returning from Casablanca]]
==Background== Volunteer pilot [[William Vanderkloot]], a US citizen serving with [[RAF Ferry Command]] since June 1941, delivered a specially modified long-range [[Consolidated Liberator II]] in July 1942. Vanderkloot was ordered to RAF headquarters where he was asked by Sir [[Charles Portal]], [[Chief of the Air Staff (United Kingdom)|Chief of the Air Staff]], if there was a safe, direct route from [[England]] to [[Cairo]], by air in the Liberator which he had just delivered to [[Prestwick Airport]]. Vanderkloot informed Portal that the flight was possible with one stop in [[Gibraltar]]. Initially heading Eastwards from Gibraltar, staying over the sea in the afternoon, and then turning sharply South after dusk, flying over [[Spain|Spanish]] and [[Vichy France|Vichy]] territory in [[Africa]] in darkness, before turning East again for the [[Nile]], approaching Cairo from the South. Thus the danger from land-based enemy aircraft in North Africa and [[Sicily]] would be largely avoided without having to fly halfway around Africa.
[[File:Royal Air Force Ferry Command, 1941-1943. CH8550.jpg|thumb|right||The Prime Minister, Winston Churchill in RAF uniform, accompanied by Air Chief Marshal Sir [[Charles Portal]], Chief of the Air Staff, leaving ''Commando'' at [[RAF Lyneham]], [[Wiltshire]], on their return from the [[Casablanca Conference]].]] Portal told Vanderkloot to "stay handy to the telephone". The next day Vanderkloot was taken to [[Winston Churchill]]'s residence at [[No.10 Downing Street]]. Churchill, clad in robe and slippers, offered him a drink, beginning a relationship that had Vanderkloot flying the Prime Minister on sensitive diplomatic trips across war-torn [[Europe]], [[Russia]], [[North Africa]] and the [[Middle-East]].<ref name=Davies>{{cite book|last1=Davies|first1=Ian|title=RAF Ferry Command : Liberator AL504, "Commando" : Winston Churchill's flights : August 1942, Cairo and Moscow : January – February 1943, Casablanca and Turkey|location=Imperial War Museum|url=http://www.iwm.org.uk/collections/item/publication/106211|accessdate=2 October 2015}}</ref><ref name=Lavery>{{Cite book |first=Brian |last=Lavery |title=Churchill Goes to War: Winston's Wartime Journeys |publisher=Naval Institute Press |year=2007 |isbn=1591141036|page=157}}</ref> "He took calculated risks," said his son, William III. There was a lot more risk in flying back then. It was a frontier, and I think all the old pilots will say it, secretly to themselves, that they enjoyed being on their own. It was the wild blue yonder." As Churchill's pilot, Vanderkloot flew [[Lord Mountbatten]] to England in June 1942, conveyed the Prime Minister and Chief of the Imperial General Staff [[Alan Brooke]] to Egypt in August 1942 to replace [[Claude Auchinleck]] commander of the British army in North Africa with [[Bernard Montgomery]] and also took Churchill to high-level talks in Moscow with Joseph Stalin, to Turkey to determine that country's wartime intentions, and to the Casablanca Conference in 1943.<ref name=Times190400>{{cite news|last1=Vanderkloot|first1=William J.|publisher=The Times|date=19 Apr 2000|location=London|page=25|title=unknown}}</ref><ref name=airspace>{{Cite journal |url=http://www.airspacemag.com/history-of-flight/Travels-with-Churchill.html |author=Graham Chandler |title=Travels with Churchill. A World War II flight engineer dishes on the most "I" of the VIPs he flew with. |journal=Air & Space magazine |date=July 2009}}</ref> [[File:American Aircraft in Royal Air Force Service 1939-1945- Consolidated Liberator. CH18804.jpg|thumb|right|interior of AL504 ''Commando'']] On delivery ''Commando'' had a regular Liberator nose and tail configuration despite the internal modifications but was later converted to have a covered nose and also to have a single tail fin. The [[Very Important Person|VIP]] ("Very Important Person[s]") interior had comfortable seating, an electric galley and even a bed, installed for Churchill.<ref name=IWM>{{cite web |title=AMERICAN AIRCRAFT IN ROYAL AIR FORCE SERVICE 1939–1945: CONSOLIDATED LIBERATOR.| url=http://www.iwm.org.uk/collections/item/object/205210637|website=Imperial War Museum| accessdate=2 October 2015}}</ref><ref name=joebaugher>{{cite web| title=Liberator II for the RAF/LB-30|url=http://www.joebaugher.com/usaf_bombers/b24_5.html | website=joebaugher.com| accessdate=2 October 2015}}</ref> After the second extended trip,<ref name=Lavery/> Churchill never again flew in ''Commando'', instead switching to ''[[Avro York#Specials|Ascalon]]'', a passenger version of the Lancaster bomber with a larger fuselage and an all-British crew. Vanderkloot and his mixed US/Canadian civilian crew were all recommended for British awards for their service, he and one other receiving honorary [[OBE]]s.<ref name=natarc>{{cite book|title=Document Air 2/6699|publisher=National Archives|location=London}}</ref>
[[File:American Aircraft in Royal Air Force Service 1939-1945- Consolidated Liberator. CH18803.jpg|thumb|right|Interior of AL504 ''Commando'']] In September 1943 Liberator AL504 was withdrawn from VIP service and flown to a [[Tucson, Arizona]] [[USAAF]] base, where it underwent major modifications and emerged as a one-off transport, lengthened by seven feet, with single tail fin, extended fuselage, and upgraded engines. AL504 flew again in March 1944 as the trial version of the [[US Navy]]’s [[Consolidated RY Liberator Express]] transport.<ref name=Merriam>{{cite book|last1=Merriam|first1=Ray|title=World War II Album Volume 7: Consolidated PB4Y-1 Liberator and PB4Y-2 Privateer|publisher=Lulu.com|isbn=978-1312961975|page=17}}</ref> Vanderkloot and the crew continued to fly it for a time, one crew member's last logbook entry for AL504 is 24 November 1944.<ref name=airspace/>
''Commando'' had served as Churchill’s official aircraft during a critical period and later in the war was also used on occasion by other VIP’s for their business in connection with the war effort. She also served with [[No. 45 Group Communications Flight]] (45 Gp Comms Flt), based at Dorval, near Montreal.<ref name=Lake>{{cite book |last=Lake |first=Alan |title=Flying Units of the RAF |year=1999 |publisher=Airlife Publishing |location=Shrewsbury |isbn=978-1-84037-086-7}}</ref> It was well maintained and proved extremely reliable and had been flown from [[Montreal]] to [[Sydney, Australia]] on 5 November 1944 by [[Air Commodore]] C J Powell CBE, [[RAF]] (Senior Air Staff Officer) [[RAF Transport Command]].<ref name=Livingstone>{{cite book|last1=Livingstone|first1=Bob|title=Under the Southern Cross : the B-24 Liberator in the South Pacific|date=1998|publisher=Turner Pub.|location=Paducah, KY|isbn=978-1563114328|page=122|edition=Limited}}</ref>
''Commando'' was the second of 139 VLR (Very Long Range) Liberator II aircraft delivered to the RAF mostly to be used by [[RAF Coastal Command]] on maritime patrol duty and anti-submarine warfare, escorting the supply convoys of merchant vessels and attacking and sinking German [[U-boat]]s.
==Last flight== The Under-Secretary of State for Air [[Rupert Brabner]] [[Distinguished Service Order|DSO]] [[Distinguished Service Cross (United Kingdom)|DSC]], his deputy Sir [[John Abraham (civil servant)|John Abraham]] KBE CB, and the Air Member for Training [[Air Marshal]] Sir [[Peter Roy Maxwell Drummond]] [[Order of the Bath|KCB]] [[Distinguished Service Order|DSO]] [[Medal bar|& Bar]] [[Order of the British Empire|OBE]] [[Military Cross|MC]] [[RAF]] needed to fly to Canada with other dignitaries to attend a ceremony marking the closure of the [[British Commonwealth Air Training Plan]]. [[Winston Churchill]]'s former personal transport ''Commando'' was assigned as the VIP aircraft.
Flown by [[Wing Commander (rank)|Wing Commander]] William Biddell OBE DFC, the aircraft took off from [[RAF Northolt]] at 23:00 hours GMT on Monday 26 March 1945 to fly to [[Ottawa]], [[Canada]] with a refueling stop at [[Lagens Field]] in the [[Azores]]. Routine contact was established between the aircraft and its base at 05:22 hours GMT in the morning with the flight proceeding as scheduled. The flight was proceeding routinely when the last contact was made with [[RAF Transport Command]] at [[RAF Prestwick]] at 07:16 hours GMT on the morning of 27 March 1945 in position 40°30'N 20°17'W by civilian Radio Officer Frederick Williams aboard the aircraft, to advise an estimated time of arrival of 08:10 hours at [[Lagens Field]]. There were no further signals.
==Loss and searches== When ''Commando'' failed to arrive at [[Lagens Field]] emergency calls were made by radio and air-sea searches initiated once the aircraft was classified as overdue. [[RAF Coastal Command]] assisted by the [[Royal Navy]] commenced a series of searches which were described by [[Prime Minister]] [[Winston Churchill]] in his announcement in the [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom|House of Commons]] on 28 March 1945. Close to the flight path which ''Commando'' would have been following over the ocean in towards [[Lagens Field]] aircrew of the searching [[RAF Coastal Command]] aircraft spotted some yellow dinghies, a small amount of wreckage and an oil patch on the surface. It was {{convert|150|-|200|mi|nmi km|abbr=on}} north-west of the Azores, there were no traces of any survivors.<ref name=Storr>{{cite web|last1=Storr|first1=Alan|title=RAAF WW2 fatalities by categories|url=http://static.awm.gov.au/images/collection/pdf/RC09125_020--1-.pdf|website=static.awm.gov.au|accessdate=2 October 2015}}</ref> Little could be done and it was considered probable that ''Commando'' had crashed at sea while approaching the Azores.<ref name=asn157730>{{cite web|title=Accident record|url=http://aviation-safety.net/wikibase/wiki.php?id=157730|website=ASN|accessdate=3 October 2015}}</ref>
==Possible causes== * Radio or radio navigational aid failure was not considered an issue as the aircraft was flying in daylight and the Azores would probably have been located without difficulty. * Engine failure was considered. The No. 2 engine had been changed during maintenance on 15 November 1944 and had 517 flying hours, the other three engines had each accumulated 466 flying hours and had been serviced on 16 November 1944. The aircraft carried its own [[flight engineer]]. Its previous civilian flight engineer, John Affleck, testified at the court of enquiry and reported that mention was made in a radio signal of an oil leak in the No. 2 engine which he believed might have resulted in a fire beside a fuel tank.<ref name=airspace/> * Fuel shortage was considered unlikely, excepting a catastrophic leak, as the aircraft carried considerably more than sufficient for its flight to the Azores. * Pilot error was considered unlikely as the aircraft was flown by a highly experienced [[RAF Transport Command]] transatlantic pilot who had 635 flying hours on Liberators and 3,780 flying hours in total. * Navigational error was discounted as the traces of wreckage were found close to the expected flight path. * Structural failure was considered, but was not confirmed due to lack of evidence from crash debris.
==The crew== ;Pilot:[[Wing Commander (rank)|Wing Commander]] William Hugh Biddell OBE DFC RAF,<ref>[http://radleyarchives.co.uk/browse/magazines/the-radleian/the-radleian-1940-1949/the-radleian-no600-june-1945/99017 Radley College Obituary – WH Biddell]</ref> aged 28, a married man from Kent, was a regular service officer who had joined the [[Royal Air Force]] and been commissioned on 21 October 1935,<ref>{{LondonGazette|issue=34219|startpage=7168|date=12 November 1935}}</ref> promoted to [[Flight Lieutenant]] on 3 September 1939 serving as a [[flight commander]] in [[No. 206 Squadron RAF]] (206 Sqn) on maritime reconnaissance and anti-shipping duties. He was awarded a [[Distinguished Flying Cross (United Kingdom)|Distinguished Flying Cross]] on 14 June 1940 for bravery in combat with enemy aircraft over the [[Dunkirk evacuation]] beaches in May 1940.<ref>{{LondonGazette|issue=34873|startpage=3622|date=14 June 1940}}</ref> and also received a "Polish Cross for Gallantry" the same month for having flown the Polish General [[Wladyslaw Sikorski]] from [[Bordeaux]] to England escaping the German occupation forces. Biddell joined the staff of [[RAF Ferry Command]] on 22 January 1942, was promoted to temporary [[Wing Commander (rank)|Wing Commander]] on 1 June 1942,<ref>{{LondonGazette|issue=35618|startpage=2927|date=3 July 1942}}</ref> and decorated as an Officer of the [[Order of the British Empire]] Military Division on 8 June 1944 for his work with [[RAF Transport Command]].<ref>{{LondonGazette|issue=36544|supp=yes|startpage=2583|date=2 June 1944}}</ref><ref name=cwgcbidd>{{cite web|title=BIDDELL, WILLIAM HUGH| url=http://www.cwgc.org/find-war-dead/casualty/1529773/BIDDELL,%20WILLIAM%20HUGH|website=cwgc.org|accessdate=3 October 2015}}</ref>
;Second Pilot: [[Flight Lieutenant]] Aubrey Norman Brodie RAFVR aged 24, from [[Birmingham]], had joined the [[RAFVR]] in 1941, learned to fly in Canada and been commissioned 9 December 1943.<ref>{{LondonGazette|issue=36399|supp=yes|startpage=997|date=25 February 1944}}</ref> He was rapidly promoted [[Flying Officer]] in June 1944 and then acting [[Flight Lieutenant]].<ref name=cwgcbrodie>{{cite web|title=BRODIE, AUBREY NORMAN|url=http://www.cwgc.org/find-war-dead/casualty/1530482/BRODIE,%20AUBREY%20NORMAN|website=cwgc.org|accessdate=3 October 2015}}</ref><ref name=moseliansbrodie>{{cite web|title=In Memory of Flight Lieutenant Aubrey Norman Brodie R.A.F.V.R. (20/02/1921 – 27/03/1945)|url=http://www.moseleians.co.uk/roll-of-honour-2/#brodie|website=moseleians.co.uk|accessdate=3 October 2015}}</ref>
;Navigator:Flight Lieutenant David Buchanan RCAF aged 29, a married man from [[Winnipeg, Manitoba]]. He was a highly experienced Navigator with [[RAF Ferry Command]] who had flown on many trans-atlantic flights.<ref name=cwgcbuch>{{cite web|title=BUCHANAN, DAVID|url=http://www.cwgc.org/find-war-dead/casualty/2622498/BUCHANAN,%20DAVID| website=cwgc.org| accessdate=3 October 2015}}</ref>
;Second Navigator:Flight Lieutenant Kenneth George Shea RAAF aged 27 born at [[Launceston, Tasmania]] he had taken part in many long range missions from [[Dorval]], initially with [[RAF Transport Command]] and since 1 March 1945 with [[No. 231 Squadron RAF]] (231 Sqn) still involved in trans-atlantic flights. Promoted to [[Flight Lieutenant]] in February 1944 he had been awarded a [[King’s Commendation for Valuable Services in the Air]] on 1 September 1944.<ref>{{LondonGazette|issue=36682|supp=yes|startpage=4076|date=29 August 1944}}</ref><ref name=awmshea>{{cite web|title=Roll of Honour: Kenneth George Shea|url=https://www.awm.gov.au/people/rolls/R1717899/|website=awm.gov.au|accessdate=3 October 2015}}</ref><ref name=cwgc>{{cite web|title=SHEA, KENNETH GEORGE|url=http://www.cwgc.org/find-war-dead/casualty/1806993/SHEA,%20KENNETH%20GEORGE| website=cwgc.org| accessdate=2 October 2015}}</ref><ref name=raafdb>{{cite web|title=FLIGHT LIEUTENANT SHEA, KENNETH GEORGE|url=http://www.raafdb.com/view_casualty.asp?id=1573|website=raafdb.com|accessdate=2 October 2015}}</ref>
;Radio Officer:Mr. Frederick Walter Williams, a civilian, employed by [[RAF Transport Command]] aged 32 from [[Gloucester]], [[Gloucestershire]].<ref name=cwgcWilliams>{{cite web|title=WILLIAMS, FREDERICK WALTER|url=http://www.cwgc.org/find-war-dead/casualty/75451484/WILLIAMS,%20FREDERICK%20WALTER|website=cwgc.org|accessdate=2 October 2015}}</ref>
;Flight Engineer:[[Warrant Officer]] Douglas James Spence (RCAF) aged 33 from [[Vancouver]], a regular service [[RCAF]] flight engineer with 17 years service who had flown the trans-atlantic route many times. He was posthumously commissioned.<ref name=cwgcSpence>{{cite web|title=SPENCE, DOUGLAS JAMES|url=http://www.cwgc.org/find-war-dead/casualty/2623074/SPENCE,%20DOUGLAS%20JAMES|website=cwgc.org|accessdate=2 October 2015}}</ref><ref name=toj>{{cite journal|journal=The Ottawa Journal|date=31 March 1945|page=17|title=unknown}}</ref>
;Flight Steward & Clerk:Mr. Victor Ian Claud James Bannister, a civilian employed by [[RAF Transport Command]] aged 29, a married man from London.<ref>[http://www.cwgc.org/find-war-dead/casualty/75451483/BANNISTER,%20VICTOR%20IAN%20CLAUDE%20JAMES War Graves details – VICJ Bannister]</ref><ref name=cwgcBann>{{cite web|title=BANNISTER, VICTOR IAN CLAUDE JAMES | url=http://www.cwgc.org/find-war-dead/casualty/75451483/BANNISTER,%20VICTOR%20IAN%20CLAUDE%20JAMES| website=cwgc.org| accessdate=2 October 2015}}</ref> [[File:Cecil Beaton Photographs- Political and Military Personalities; Drummond, Peter Roy Maxwell CBM1478.jpg|thumb|right|Air Marshal Sir Peter Drummond]]
==The VIPs== ; Commander [[Rupert Arnold Brabner]] [[Distinguished Service Order|DSO]] [[Distinguished Service Cross (United Kingdom)|DSC]] [[Royal Navy]]:([[Parliamentary Under Secretary of State for Air]]) A 33 year old married man. Brabner was an M.A. graduate of [[Cambridge University]], elected [[Member of Parliament]] for [[Hythe, Kent]] and a serving [[Fleet Air Arm]] ace fighter pilot.<ref>{{LondonGazette |issue=36143 |supp=yes |startpage=3785 |date=20 August 1943}}</ref><ref>{{LondonGazette |issue=35687|supp=yes |startpage=3817 |date=28 August 1942}}</ref> He was born in [[Chelsea, London]] on 29 October 1911. Educated at [[Felstead School]], Essex and [[St Catharine's College, Cambridge|St. Catharine’s College]], [[Cambridge]] and was an elected member of [[London County Council]] and then [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]] [[Member of Parliament]] from July 1939.<ref>{{LondonGazette |issue=34648 |supp=yes |startpage=5104 |date=25 July 1939}}</ref> He was decorated for his success as a [[Fleet Air Arm]] fighter pilot for actions over [[Malta]]. Brabner was "Technical Assistant" to the [[Fifth Sea Lord]] at the Admiralty 1943–44 and then "Assistant Government Parliamentary Whip" before being appointed Under Secreaty of State for Air in November 1944.<ref name=cwgcbrab>{{cite web|title=BRABNER, RUPERT ARNOLD|url=http://www.cwgc.org/find-war-dead/casualty/2973896/BRABNER,%20RUPERT%20ARNOLD|website=cwgc.org|accessdate=2 October 2015}}</ref><ref name=wwwv.4131>{{cite book|title=Who was who. vol. 4. 1941–1950 : a companion to Who's who, containing the biographies of those who diedduring the period of 1941–1950.|date=1967| page=131|publisher=A. and C. Black| location=London| isbn=978-0713601718| edition=4th}}</ref>
;[[Air Marshal]] Sir [[Peter Roy Maxwell Drummond]] [[Order of the Bath|KCB]] [[Distinguished Service Order|DSO]] [[Medal bar|& Bar]] [[Order of the British Empire|OBE]] [[Military Cross|MC]] [[RAF]]:(Air Member for Training)
;Sir John Bradley Abraham KBE CB:(Deputy Under Secretary of State (Air Ministry)) A 63 year old married man from [[Radlett]] in [[Hertfordshire]].<ref name=wwwv.43>{{cite book|title=Who was who. vol. 4. 1941–1950 : a companion to Who's who, containing the biographies of those who diedduring the period of 1941–1950.|date=1967| page=3|publisher=A. and C. Black|location=London|isbn=978-0713601718|edition=4th}}</ref> Abraham joined the [[British Civil Service]] as a Boy in 1897, progressing to Class I Clerk at the [[Admiralty]] in 1912, and then "Assistant Principal Clerk" (Air Ministry) in 1918.<ref>{{LondonGazette| issue=28595 |startpage=2413 |date=2 April 1912}}</ref><ref>{{London Gazette |issue=13284 |date=5 July 1918 |startpage=2341 |city=e }}</ref> Appointed a Companion of the [[Most Honourable Order of the Bath]] in January 1933 as Assistant Secretary of State at the [[Air Ministry]].<ref>{{LondonGazette|issue=33898 |supp=yes| startpage=4|date=30 December 1932}}</ref> He was Knighted on 1 January 1942.<ref>{{LondonGazette |issue=35399 |supp=yes|startpage=14|date=30 December 1941}}</ref><ref name=cwgcabra>{{cite web| title=ABRAHAM, Sir JOHN BRADLEY| url=http://www.cwgc.org/find-war-dead/casualty/3168791/ABRAHAM,%20Sir%20JOHN%20BRADLEY|website=cwgc.org| accessdate=2 October 2015}}</ref><ref>[http://www.gettyimages.co.uk/detail/news-photo/no-ch-4705-mr-john-bradley-abraham-cb-deputy-under-news-photo/138602241 Getty Images – JB Abraham]</ref><ref name=Getty>{{cite web| title=Mr John Bradley Abraham, CB| url=http://www.gettyimages.co.uk/detail/news-photo/no-ch-4705-mr-john-bradley-abraham-cb-deputy-under-news-photo/138602241| website=gettyimages.co.uk| publisher=No.CH.4705 (Air Ministry Photograph – Crown Copyright Reserved)| accessdate=2 October 2015}}</ref>
;Mr. Henry Albert Jones CMG MC Croix de Guerre with Palm:(Air Delegation (Washington) and United Kingdom Air Liaison Mission (Ottawa)) A 51 year old married man from [[Chingford]].<ref name=wwwv.4614>{{cite book|title=Who was who. vol. 4. 1941–1950 : a companion to Who's who, containing the biographies of those who diedduring the period of 1941–1950.|date=1967| page=614|publisher=A. and C. Black|location=London|isbn=978-0713601718|edition=4th}}</ref> Jones had served in [[World War I]] with the [[Wiltshire Regiment]] and as an observer with the [[Royal Flying Corps]] being awarded a [[Military Cross]] for conspicuous gallantry in France, and also a [[Croix de Guerre 1914-1918]] with Palm.<ref>{{London Gazette |issue=13155 |date=22 October 1917 |startpage=2191 |city=e }}</ref><ref>{{LondonGazette |issue=30561| supp=yes| startpage=2921|date=5 March 1918}}</ref><ref>{{London Gazette |issue=13181 |date=19 December 1917 |startpage=2619 |city=e }}</ref> After military service he was Gazetted to the [[Department of Overseas Trade (United Kingdom)|Department of Overseas Trade]] as an "Intelligence Officer".<ref>{{LondonGazette |issue=32812 |startpage=2584 |date=6 April 1923}}</ref> Jones was British government official air historian and author of 31 published works documenting the official story of the war in the air 1914–18.<ref name=worldcat>{{cite web|title=Jones, H. A. (Henry Albert) 1893–1945| url=http://www.worldcat.org/identities/viaf-25549613/|website=worldcat.org| accessdate=2 October 2015}}</ref> He was seconded to the Cabinet Office in the 1930s and then to the Air Staff Secretariat in 1939, becoming Director of Public Relations (Air Ministry) in 1944.<ref name=Crowson>{{cite book|editor1-last=Crowson|editor1-first=N.J.|title=Fleet Street, press barons and politics : the journals of Collin Brooks, 1932–1940| date=1998|publisher=Camridge Univ. Press| location=Cambridge| isbn=978-0521662390 |page=52n }}<!--| accessdate=2 October 2015--></ref> He was appointed a Companion of the Most Distinguished [[Order of St Michael and St George]] on 1 January 1943.<ref>{{LondonGazette |issue=35841| startpage=5 |date=29 December 1942}}</ref><ref name=cwgcJones>{{cite web|title=JONES, HENRY ALBERT|url=http://www.cwgc.org/find-war-dead/casualty/3168821/JONES,%20HENRY%20ALBERT|website=cwgc.org|accessdate=2 October 2015}}</ref>
;Mr. Edward Twentyman:(Civil Service) A 57 year old married man from [[Chatham, Kent]] born at [[Bolton, Lancashire]] educated at [[London University]]. Worked in the [[India Office]] from 1910 and as "Principal Assistant" at the Treasury in 1920.<ref>{{LondonGazette|issue=31802|startpage=2488|date=2 March 1920}}</ref><ref>[http://www.cwgc.org/find-war-dead/casualty/3168841/TWENTYMAN,%20EDWARD War Graves details – E Twentyman]</ref><ref name=cwgcTman>{{cite web|title=TWENTYMAN, EDWARD|url=http://www.cwgc.org/find-war-dead/casualty/3168841/TWENTYMAN,%20EDWARD|website=cwgc.org|accessdate=2 October 2015}}</ref>
;Mr. Eric Robinson:(Civil Service) A 35 year old married man from [[Southport, Lancashire]] living in [[Bromley, Kent]].<ref name=cwgcrob>{{cite web|title=ROBINSON, ERIC|url=http://www.cwgc.org/find-war-dead/casualty/3168830/ROBINSON,%20ERIC|website=cwgc.org|accessdate=2 October 2015}}</ref>
;[[Squadron Leader]] Elisha Gaddis Plum RAFVR: (UK Air Liaison Mission) A 47 year old married man resident in [[Chelsea, London]] and [[Rumson, New Jersey]],<ref>[http://www.thepeerage.com/p34547.htm Peerage, p.34547 – EG Plum]</ref> a US citizen working with the United Kingdom Air Liaison Mission. Gaddis Plum joined the [[RAFVR]] and was commissioned on 1 June 1940 as a [[Pilot Officer]] in the "Equipment Branch",<ref>{{LondonGazette|issue=34881|startpage=3871|date=25 June 1940}}</ref> he was promoted [[Flight Lieutenant]] on 11 June 1943 and acting [[Squadron Leader]]<ref name=cwgcplum>{{cite web|title=PLUM, ELISHA GADDIS|url=http://www.cwgc.org/find-war-dead/casualty/1804441/PLUM,%20ELISHA%20GADDIS|website=cwgc.org|accessdate=2 October 2015}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==Further reading== *{{cite book| last1=Andrade| first1=John M.|title=U.S. military aircraft designations and serials 1909 to 1979| date=1997| publisher=Midland Counties Publications|location=Leicester| isbn=0-904597-22-9}} * {{cite book|last1=Birdsall|first1=Steve|title=The B-24 Liberator|date=1968|publisher=Arco Pub.|location=New York|isbn=0-668-01695-7}} * {{cite book|last1=Birdsall| first1=Steve|title=B-24 Liberator in Action – Aircraft No. 21| location=Carrollton, Texas| date=October 1979|publisher=Squadron/Signal Publications|isbn=978-0897470209}} * {{cite book|last1=Birdsall|first1=Steve|last2=Color illus. by Preston|first2=John|title=Log of the Liberators : an illustrated history of the B-24|date=1973|publisher=Doubleday & Company, Inc.|location=New
